celebrating-communities.title: Celebrating communities
celebrating-communities.description: Working on a shoestring budget doesn’t mean you can’t deliver a big change. All across Scotland, small voluntary groups and grassroots organisations do extraordinary work with local communities and communities of interest. This is a chance to celebrate their amazing work.

charity-champion.title: Charity champion
charity-champion.description: Inspiring individuals help transform our society every day. If you know an exceptional and influential person who demonstrates outstanding dedication to a charity or cause, then they could be the Charity Champion 2019.

charity-of-the-year.title: Charity of the year
charity-of-the-year.description: Simply the best, better than all the rest? We’re looking for charities and other voluntary sector organisations that have had a record breaking year over the last 12 months.Has your organisation stepped up a gear? Have you reached significant goals, celebrated outstanding achievements and taken an innovative approach? If so this award is for you.

cracking-campaign.title: Cracking campaign
cracking-campaign.description: Campaigning is at the heart of Scotland’s voluntary sector – transforming attitudes, raising funds, changing laws and raising awareness of important issues. Has your campaign finished with a bang this year or achieved a significant milestone? Did you deliver a unique, exciting and effective campaign? If so, this award is for you.

demonstrating-digital.title: Demonstrating digital
demonstrating-digital.description: The digital revolution has already happened. New technology and the internet have changed the way we live our lives. We’re looking for organisations who have adapted and evolved to maximise these opportunities.

leading-light.title: Leading light
leading-light.description: Scottish charities, social enterprises and voluntary organisations are full of inspiring individuals and leaders who help transform our society day in and day out. If you know an exceptional and influential person who demonstrates outstanding dedication to a charity or cause, then they could be named the Leading Light of 2019.

pioneering-project.title: Pioneering project
pioneering-project.description: Creative project work is the life blood of Scotland’s voluntary sector. With innovative ideas and plenty of enthusiasm, it is possible to make a significant impact from a project or partnership. If you’re delivering a service or a project that is making a big difference to a community, then this is the award for you.

terrific-trustee.title: Terrific trustee
terrific-trustee.description: There are thousands of inspiring individuals who make a huge contribution to transforming our society by sitting on charity boards. If you know an exceptional and influential trustee who demonstrates outstanding dedication to a charity or cause, then they could be named the Terrific Trustee 2019.

questions.title: Organisation type

options.answer: Charity
Company

section-1.name: Organisational purpose
section-1.title: Organisational purpose
section-1.heading: A well-run board is clear about the purpose and values of the organisation and how it will achieve its aims.
section-1.description: As the board we have ultimate responsibility for directing the activity of our organisation and delivering its stated purpose.

questions.title: Understanding our organisational purpose and values and committing to them to make sure that our organisation delivers what it was set up to do

options.answer: All trustees have a copy of our governing document
All trustees have read and understand our governing document
All trustees can commit to our organisation's purpose and articulate this clearly
We have identified and mapped our activities against our organisational purpose and the needs of our beneficiaries, and they are consistent
We have developed and agreed a written statement outlining our organisation's mission (what it aims to do), values, and objectives

questions.title: Making sure our governing document is fit for purpose, and sets out the details of how our organisation is to be governed

options.answer: Our governing document is available for reference at board meetings
Our governing document contains details of the minimum number of trustees required
Our governing document contains a realistic quorum figure
Our governing document is reviewed annually to make sure it is fit for purpose

questions.title: Making and recording informed decisions in line with our governing document

options.answer: We keep consistent minutes of meetings that record attendance, order of business, decisions and actions
Our minutes of meetings are approved in line with the rules set out in our governing document

questions.title: Overseeing the use of assets and resources to make sure they are used to achieve our organisation's purpose and aims

options.answer: We have compiled an asset and resource register which is regularly reviewed
Our board receives regular information on our organisation's activities, assets and resources, and progress against targets

questions.title: Communicating the work of the organisation and the difference it makes to the people we work with and the public

options.answer: We produce an annual report with details of our accounts and activities every year
Our annual report is widely available and easy to access on our website

We have a communications strategy which details how best to communicate with all of our stakeholders about how we're governed, and our values, work and achievements in delivering our organisational purpose

section-2.name: Leadership
section-2.title: Leadership
section-2.heading: A well-run board is clear about its role and responsibilities and provides strategic direction in line with the organisation's purpose, vision and values.
section-2.description: As the board we are here to lead our organisation, and we are individually and collectively responsible for our decisions. We need to make sure our organisation has a clear strategy to achieve our purpose.

questions.title: Identifying and embedding the vision and values of our organisation, and making sure these underpin all our decisions and activities

options.answer: We have developed and agreed a written statement outlining our mission (what we aim to do), values and objectives
Our mission, values and objectives underpin all of our work, activities and culture and all board decisions

questions.title: Having a clear understanding of the individual and collective roles and responsibilities of our board

options.answer: Our trustees have written role descriptions
We ensure our trustees understand their duties and responsibilities under the Charities and Trustee Investment Act (Scotland) 2005
We ensure our directors understand their duties and responsibilities under the Companies Act 2006
All trustees value collective decision making and understand they're all part of the leadership team and equally accountable for decisions made and their outcomes
The importance of collective decision making is reinforced through induction, regular training and performance review
All trustees understand and are familiar with The Scottish Governance Code for the Third Sector

questions.title: Setting the tone through our leadership, behaviour, culture and overall performance

options.answer: All trustees are committed to leading and creating impact through engagement with stakeholders
All trustees are committed to leading and creating impact by being open and transparent in our governance
We have a code of conduct that our trustees have signed up to and adhere to
We have a register of interests where trustees declare all interests in other organisations and businesses that could conflict with their role
Trustees are aware of conflicts of interest caused by personal relationships

questions.title: Promoting equality and diversity throughout the organisation

options.answer: We have an Equal Opportunities policy and action plan to promote equality and diversity on the board and throughout our organisation
Our board is prepared to ask difficult questions and challenge itself to enable it to make better decisions
Our board take part in diversity training and understand their responsibilities in this area
Our staff and volunteers take part in diversity training and understand their responsibilities in this area
Our volunteers take part in diversity training and understand their responsibilities in this area
Our services and information are accessible to all

questions.title: Communicating with our staff, volunteers and members about our vision for the organisation and the decisions we make, and listening to feedback

options.answer: We have a communications strategy which details how best to communicate with all of our stakeholders about how we're governed, and our values, work and achievements in delivering our organisational purpose
We have an accessible list of trustees
We have clear information about members' role in the governance of our organisation (if applicable)

questions.title: Leading and overseeing progress and performance by scrutinising information on activities and achievements, and their longer-term impact

options.answer: Our board receives regular information on our organisation's activities, assets and resources, and progress against targets
We evaluate the impact of our organisation

questions.title: Understanding and respecting the difference between governance and operations, delegating operational tasks where appropriate, recognising that responsibility and accountability is always retained by the board

options.answer: Our board focusses on strategy, performance and assurance, rather than operational matters
We have a scheme of delegation consistent with our governing document, to provide clarity around who has authority to make different decisions
We have clear role descriptions for trustees
We have clear role descriptions for volunteers
We have terms of reference for any sub-committees
We have job descriptions for staff (where applicable)

section-3.name: Board behaviour
section-3.title: Board behaviour
section-3.heading: A well-run board, both collectively and individually, embraces and demonstrates mutual respect, integrity, openness and accountability.
section-3.description: As the board we understand that our behaviour can have a far-reaching impact and is fundamental to our organisation's reputation and success. We need to ensure our behaviour is consistent with our organisation's vision and values.

questions.title: Being transparent, open and accountable about how we govern, who we are, and the decisions we make

options.answer: Providing public access to our governing document and annual report with an accessible list of trustees
If a charity, ensuring that external documents and communications display our name as entered on the Scottish Charity Register and Scottish Charity Number

If a membership organisation, providing clear information about membership eligibility and participation, and the role of members in the governance of our organisation taking members' views into account on key issues
Having clear policies on expenses, hospitality and gifts, and payment of trustees, in line with our governing document

questions.title: Making sure our organisation promotes equality and diversity and embeds ethical standards in the policies, practices and culture of our organisation

options.answer: Recognising our organisation's responsibility towards communities, stakeholders, wider society and the environment, and acting on them in a manner consistent with our purposes
Having an Equal Opportunities policy and action plan to promote equality and diversity on our board and throughout our organisation.
Ensuring our board, staff and volunteers take part in diversity training and understand their responsibilities in this area
Ensuring our services and information are accessible to all

Fundraising ethically and in line with our organisation's purpose and values. The board should have a fundraising strategy consistent with regulations and guidance on fundraising, that complies with the Code of Fundraising Practice
Recruiting and employing our staff fairly and in accordance with equal opportunities legislation, paying staff at least the Living Wage
Having an easily accessible whistleblowing policy

questions.title: Listening to each other, our beneficiaries, members, employees, volunteers and stakeholders, and respecting the role they each play

options.answer: Being clear about who our beneficiaries and key stakeholders are, for example through an accurate and up to date register of members, records of service users, details of funders
Communicating effectively with all our stakeholders, providing them with opportunities to contribute their views on key issues

If a membership organisation, providing clear information about membership eligibility and participation, and the role of members in the governance of our organisation taking members' views into account on key issues
Providing clear role descriptions for our trustees and volunteers, and terms of reference for any sub-committees, and job descriptions for staff

questions.title: Handling concerns and complaints transparently, constructively and impartially

options.answer: Having an easily accessible and transparent complaints process which is communicated widely
Ensuring our board receives a regular report on the number and type of complaints received
If engaged in fundraising, ensuring our complaints handling process is in line with guidance from the Code of Fundraising Practice

questions.title: Recognising and acknowledging where conflicts of interest may arise

options.answer: Making time and space for our trustees to discuss issues of ‘conflict of interest' and ‘conflict of loyalty' so we can develop a policy that we all understand and adhere to. This should help trustees who also act in other roles in the organisation understand the distinction between their roles and responsibilities
Ensuring our trustees declare all interests in other organisations and businesses that could conflict with their role and are aware of conflicts of interest caused by personal relationships
Having conflicts of interest as a standing item on the agenda, with any declared conflicts of interest included in the minutes

questions.title: Creating a constructive board environment where diverse, and at times conflicting views are respected and welcomed, and decisions are reached collectively

options.answer: Ensuring all trustee voices are heard equally in meetings, where there is an open culture of trust and support, and a safe space to challenge. This is evidenced in our minutes

Designing a code of conduct that our trustees sign up and adhere to. This should outline expected standards of behaviour eg attendance at meetings, the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of board meetings, and what happens if they are not met. It should be reviewed regularly to ensure it meets developing ethical standards expected by stakeholders and society

section-4.name: Control
section-4.title: Control
section-4.heading: A well-run board will develop and implement appropriate controls to direct and oversee progress and performance of the organisation.
section-4.description: As the board we should put in place appropriate structures, controls and processes to make sure the organisation is run in line with its purposes and values, governing document, and relevant legal and regulatory requirements.

questions.title: Maintaining and regularly reviewing policies and procedures and reporting arrangements, for example our internal governance, safeguarding, fundraising and financial controls

options.answer: Ensuring our organisation meets its legal, regulatory and contractual obligations and any constitutional requirements, eg by registering with the appropriate regulating bodies, completing OSCR or Companies House annual returns and accounts on time, understanding our tax obligations, and complying with HMRC requirements

Creating and regularly reviewing our policies and procedures which may include:
  • Data protection
  • Finance Fundraising
  • Health and Safety
  • HR and Employment
  • Insurance
  • Lobbying
  • Record Keeping
  • Safeguarding
  • Volunteering

questions.title: Making sure our scrutiny and collective decision-making processes are rigorous, informed, transparent, timely and well communicated

options.answer: Ensuring all our trustees have a copy of our governing document and refer to it as necessary when making decisions, with a clear understanding of our powers
Providing our trustees with board reports that are timely, concise and factual, and clear about the decisions that are needed
Ensuring our accounts are externally audited or independently examined and made publicly available

questions.title: Understanding and analysing the internal and external operating environments of the organisation to create effective strategies and systems for risk management

options.answer: Monitoring the external environment to ensure our organisation's purposes remain relevant and planning for sustainability
Analysing the risks our organisation faces, and forming a clear approach to managing those risks with a risk management policy and risk register which is regularly reviewed

questions.title: Monitoring and evaluating performance against operational plans and budgets

options.answer: Ensuring our organisation has an income strategy with a clear understanding of the income needed and a business plan to show how we will generate it
Regularly reviewing the sustainability of our income sources and business model in the short, medium and long term, and identifying diversified income streams
Providing our board with staff and/or volunteer reports and regular financial reports, and tools and the knowledge to evaluate our impact by measuring and assessing outputs and outcomes
Preparing an operational plan with clear targets of what we seek to achieve in the current year
Reporting to funders

questions.title: Ensuring that any contracts are agreed and carried out in line with the interests of our organisation and in line with our values

options.answer: Ensuring that all agreements and contracts are regularly reviewed and kept securely, and contractors are properly supervised and managed, to protect our organisation's interests

Fundraising ethically and in line with our organisation's purpose and values, with a fundraising strategy consistent with regulations and guidance on fundraising, that complies with the Code of Fundraising Practice

questions.title: Considering whether our organisation's legal and governance structure provides appropriate protection for the organisation, our trustees, and our members

options.answer: Regularly reviewing our legal structure, and understanding any risks involved in our organisation's work
Keeping up to date on changes in legislation and regulation, and accessing specialist advice and support if needed

questions.title: Ensuring there are robust internal financial controls in place and clear information provided to the board to allow it to monitor the organisation's financial position

options.answer: Recognising the importance of financial management to good governance and ensuring all our trustees understand their collective financial responsibilities
Ensuring our organisation's activities and spending are in line with our governing document and any investments are properly and prudently managed

questions.title: Being clear about where we delegate to staff, volunteers or committees and how we exercise oversight

options.answer: Developing a scheme of delegation consistent with our governing document, to help provide clarity around who has authority to make different decisions. This should be regularly reviewed and available to all our trustees, staff and volunteers, so everyone is clear about their roles and responsibilities, and legal liabilities
Providing clear role descriptions for our trustees and volunteers, terms of reference for any sub-committees, and job descriptions for staff

section-5.name: Effectiveness
section-5.title: Effectiveness
section-5.heading: A well-run board understands its role, powers and duties, and works collectively and proactively to achieve its organisational purpose.
section-5.description: As the board we should be self-aware and work together as a team, with a diverse and appropriate balance of skills and experience to continually improve the governance of our organisation.

questions.title: Understanding the legal structure and governing document of our organisation and making sure we act in line with it

options.answer: Ensuring that all our trustees have read and understand our governing document and understand any risks
Ensuring our governing document is available for reference at board meetings and regularly reviewed to make sure it is fit for purpose

questions.title: Setting, embedding and scrutinising the strategic direction of the organisation

options.answer: Preparing, developing and implementing an effective strategy for our organisation

questions.title: Regularly reviewing our performance and the composition and skills of the board

options.answer: Ensuring we have a yearly board review which includes an audit of the skills, knowledge and experience of our board as a whole, the chair, individual board members, committees, training and recruitment plans

questions.title: Developing and improving our capacity and capability with on-going support and training

options.answer: Continually working to develop our board through access to training opportunities and regular board away days which offer us an opportunity to work together as a team, identify board objectives and consider our strategic plan

questions.title: Having a pro-active succession plan, which is linked to the strategic direction of the organisation, following any rules for how trustees are elected and how long they serve

options.answer: Ensuring our governing document details a transparent system for both the recruitment and removal of trustees, with fixed terms of office and an effective and manageable board size
Where trustees are elected by members ensuring they are supported to make an informed choice

Ensuring our trustees are appointed, resign or retire according to our governing document and we keep appropriate records of trustees with details of when their term is up and if they are eligible to stand again
If a charity, ensuring we keep a list of all trustees' names and addresses, when they came into office and when they resign. Any trustee changes are included in our Trustees Annual Report
If a company, ensuring we keep an accurate and up to date register of members and directors and inform Companies House of any changes to our directors

questions.title: Having a transparent and timely trustee recruitment and induction process

options.answer: Ensuring our recruitment process is formal, rigorous and transparent, and based on merit and objective criteria to ensure a diverse pool of candidates
Making potential trustees aware of the time commitment of the role from the outset

Ensuring new trustees receive a full induction which includes a copy of our governing document and the Scottish Governance Code They should understand their roles and responsibilities and if possible, be linked with an existing trustee to act as a mentor

Having prospective trustees sign a form before their election to confirm they are not disqualified. There are a number of things that can disqualify a person from being a charity trustee or company director and it is the responsibility of both the individual disqualified and the board to collectively ensure that no trustees are disqualified. OSCR require charity trustees setting up a new charity to fill in a Charity Trustee Declaration Form. This can be adapted for any prospective new trustees

questions.title: Making sure our meetings enable us to explore key issues and reach well-considered collective and recorded decisions that are acted on

options.answer: Ensuring all trustees know what is expected of them at meetings and what information they will be given
Ensuring our board agendas are clearly planned to allow discussion on key strategic issues and sent out in a timely fashion to give our trustees sufficient time to prepare
Providing our trustees with board reports that are timely, concise and factual, and clear about the decisions that are needed
Ensuring that consistent minutes of meetings are kept that record attendance, order of business, decisions and actions, and are approved in line with the rules set out in our governing document
Ensuring individual trustees have reasonable access to independent professional advice where they think it necessary to fulfil their legal responsibilities

questions.title: Ensuring that meetings are well-organised, well-informed, effectively chaired and there is active participation

options.answer: Creating a Governance Calendar which details dates of meetings, away days, training events, AGM, etc
Starting and finishing meetings on time, allowing enough time for discussion, and ensuring maximum participation by all our trustees
Ensuring all meetings are quorate and that our governing document sets out rules for making decisions in an emergency or when meetings are not quorate
Ensuring our chair has support, training and access to advice

questions.title: Communicating with those who have a legitimate interest in the work of our organisation

options.answer: Identifying our key stakeholders and ensuring there is a strategy in place for communicating with them about how our organisation delivers its purpose and how it is governed
Holding an annual meeting of our members (where applicable) in line with our governing document to report on our activities
Including our legal and charitable status on all publicity information
Producing an annual report with details of our accounts and activities every year, which is widely available and easy to access
Completing OSCR or Companies House (if applicable) annual returns and accounts on time
Selecting a named person authorised to speak on the organisation's behalf

questions.title: Test

options.answer: This
or this (either)

partials.sector_stats:
The Scottish voluntary sector View the latest sector stats

 

Over 1 million people volunteered in Scotland last year

 

There are over 250,000 charity trustees across the country

 

Last year, 4/5 Scots used a voluntary sector organisation

 

There are 40,000+ voluntary sector organisations in Scotland

 

Two thirds of sector income is earned, not donated

 

In 2017, the voluntary sector had an annual turnover of £5.8 billion

 

Scotland’s voluntary sector has over 100,000 paid staff

 

78% of charities in Scotland are local

{{> headers_splash headerTextOverride="Training opportunities" typeOverride="page"}}

CJS training - courses available

Filter

Training is crucial to the development of all CJS employees. We can pay for £200 worth of training whilst the individual is employed through CJS.

This flexible training fund does not necessary need to be utilised for CJS job related training courses, it can be used by the individual for their personal development or to help enhance their future career goals.

CJS employees should speak to their employer/supervisor to book a place on a course.

Employers should login to the Salesforce portal and submit an individual training request. Please email any queries to the CJS Training Team.

Below are some examples of courses which can be accessed to utilise CJS employees training fund and training provider website links.

templates.jobs_cjs-vacancy-phase:
• Home
  • Jobs
  • Community Jobs Scotland
  • Vacancies
{{> headers_splash headerTextOverride="CJS vacancies" typeOverride="page"}}

Community Jobs Scotland (CJS) creates work opportunities for young unemployed people within voluntary sector organisations throughout Scotland.

CJS is targeted at more vulnerable young people and in particular, is focused on groups of young people who are more disadvantaged in the labour market.

{{#if @root.data.auth ~}} {{else}}

If you work for SDS or JCP please sign in.

{{/if ~}}

Start your search using the following links

16–29 year olds

The following vacancies are only open to vulnerable unemployed 16 to 29 year olds, including carers, early service leavers (armed forces), care experienced, disabled, and young people with convictions and who are not on Specialist Employability Support (SES) {{!-- Search --}}

16–29 year olds (part-time)

The following vacancies are only open to vulnerable unemployed 16 to 29 year olds, including carers, early service leavers (armed forces), care experienced, disabled, and young people with convictions who are not able to sustain 25 hours of work per week and who are not on Specialist Employability Support (SES). {{!-- Search --}}

templates.pages_charity-awards-vote-foot:
<script>
  {{#if @root.request.params.query.sg_sessionid}}
    window.location.hash = '#vote';
  {{/if}}
  console.log('Registering jQuery on load');
  $(function() {
    window.setTimeout(function() {
      var voteSuccessElement = $('#vote-success');
      console.log('Checking vote success element', voteSuccessElement);
      if (voteSuccessElement.length > 0) {
        console.log('Setting redirect vars');
        var slug = {{{stringify (default @root.request.params.vote '')}}};
        var category = {{{stringify (default @root.request.params.category '')}}};

        console.log('Getting charity awards cookie');
        var cookie = scvo.getCookie('charity_awards_already_voted');
        console.log('Got cookie', cookie);

        if (slug && category) {
          console.log('Got a slug and category.', slug, category);
          console.log('Setting cookie');
          scvo.setCookie('charity_awards_already_voted', slug, 90);
          if (!cookie) {
            console.log('As there was no previous cookie, firing GA event');
            gtag('event', 'charity-awards-2019', {
              event_category: category,
              event_label: slug
            });
          }
          console.log('Redirecting back to finalist page');
          window.location.href = '/scottish-charity-awards/vote-2019/' + category + '/' + slug + '#vote';
        } else {
          console.log('No slug or category specified. Redirecting to main finalist list');
          window.location.href = '/scottish-charity-awards/vote-2019';
        }
      }
    }, 5000);
  });
</script>

{{> headers_splash headerTextOverride="Digital Check-up Results" headerTextCaptionOverride=@root.request.params.query.web_organisation}}

If you want to see how you compare to organisations of a similar size, please enter your income bracket as you complete the survey.

{{/if ~}}

Book a follow-up call to review your results and explore next steps

{{#if @root.request.params.query.topic ~}} {{#compare @root.request.params.query.topic "===" "leadership" ~}}

The area that you selected as your highest priority was leadership, culture, and skills

You scored {{> to_percentage score=@root.request.params.query.s1 lower=-4 upper=20}}% compared to an average of {{round @root.data.supplimentaryResponses.data_averages.aggregations.leadership_culture_and_skills_stats.avg "up"}}% for all organisations who have completed the checkup.

"Digitally mature" organisations are those who recognise the value of digital technology and embedded it throughout their organisation, including; their overall strategy, their board of trustees; a digitally engaged leadership team and a digitally confident staff team.

The 2018 Charity Digital Skills Report reveals that 45% of charities who took part did not have a digital strategy. Developing a Digital Strategy is good way to start embracing the strategic advantages that digital offers. But digital technologies are an enabler for the whole of your organisation, not just your digital or communications function. So an important further step is to embed digital throughout your overall strategy.

  1. Cultivate a culture that is receptive to new ways of working Leaders from across Scotland's voluntary sector have drawn up a manifesto; "Creating a digitally confident voluntary sector in Scotland: a call to action" to commit to seizing the opportunities presented by new technology and the internet. Join us on 23rd October for a followup event – "Digitally Confident Scotland – making it happen"  
  2. Understand and improve the skills in your organisation Increased digital skills and confidence are not just useful for you as an organisation, but also for you staff team in their personal and professional lives. Use the basic digital skills framework and questionnaire to assess your staff and/or volunteers across 5 key areas: Managing information; Communicating; Transacting; Problem solving; and Creating. If you're interested in boosting the digital skills of people and communities you work with, check out our Digital Champions Training.  
  3. Further reading on Digital Leadership and Culture:
  • The 7 digital skills every charity leader needs The New Reality – Report
  • Charity Digital Toolkit - chapter 2 – Leadership
{{else}} {{#compare @root.request.params.query.topic "===" "tools" ~}}

The area that you selected as your highest priority was ICT (tools and equipment)

You scored {{> to_percentage score=@root.request.params.query.s2 lower=-2 upper=35}}% compared to an average of {{round @root.data.supplimentaryResponses.data_averages.aggregations.tools_and_equipment_stats.avg "up"}}% for all organisations who have completed the checkup.

IT tools and systems are a key part of digital change. Ideally you want them to be a positive enabler rather than a barrier. If your tools and systems are making you say 'no' to new ways of working, you may be using the wrong tools. Cloud based services and open standards mean that many more solutions are available at low or no cost. A great starting point is the Charity Catalogue which lists helpful tools and platforms suitable for charities of all sizes.

  1. Cloud Computing: If you're not already using cloud-based services, this is a quick win. Moving to the cloud offers many benefits for charities, including reduced costs, ease of access, easily scalable and increased security. The NCVO guide: How to move to the cloud is an excellent starting point. Also check out the Tech Trust for comparisons and discounted software for charities.
  2. Talk to your IT provider: Discussing your issues and describing the experience you want with your provider can make a big difference to the service you are provided.  
  3. Talk to someone else: Getting a second opinion and even looking for a new provider could help solve your issues. The SCVO IT team can provide some advice and also offer a managed IT service to Scottish charities, including: specialised advice on cloud services such as Office 365, support to find and buy the best equipment and software, help with switching to new computers and systems.  
  4. Online giving: According to Blackbaud's 2016 Charitable Giving Report, only 7.2% of all individual donations to charities in the UK were made online. But about 50% of potential donors would prefer to give online. See UK Fundraising for a roundup of free or low cost online fundraising tools.
{{else}} {{#compare @root.request.params.query.topic "===" "data" ~}}

The area that you selected as your highest priority was content, marketing, and data

You scored {{> to_percentage score=@root.request.params.query.s3 lower=-10 upper=66}}% compared to an average of {{round @root.data.supplimentaryResponses.data_averages.aggregations.content_marketing_and_data_stats.avg "up"}}% for all organisations who have completed the checkup.

This section focuses on three elements; how you understand your audiences, how you communicate with your audiences, and the management of the data you collect.

Content types

Social media allows you to reach thousands of people online, and inspire conversations amongst your supporters. But to do this well, you need engaging content. The Business Gateway's "Creating Engaging Content Guide" can help you to understand the needs of your users and how you could add to what you already do.

Marketing

There are lots of free resources on marketing in the Charity Comms knowledge hub. See also a useful introduction to harnessing audience insight for effective fundraising on Charity Choice.

Service design

If you're building an online service to help your beneficiaries, you might want to check out Better Digital's service design principles.

Explore the Charity Catalogue for new tools

A great starting point is the Charity Catalogue which lists helpful tools and platforms suitable for charities of all sizes.

Our top 10 tools

  1. Salesforce: An enterprise-level CRM, available free to charities for up to 10 users. Complex to set up though.
  2. Slack: A multi-platform messaging systems, replaces email with in our team
  3. Trello: A very powerful collaborative planning tool
  4. Canva: A very handy online graphics editor, ideal for social media images
  5. Zoom: Simple, flexible and reliable video conferencing.
  6. Mailchimp: Email campaign system. Free for small lists
  7. Tweetdeck: Powerful Twitter management and scheduling tool
  8. Cloud storage: (Microsoft 365 or G Suite). If you're not in the cloud you should be.
  9. Google Analytics: Worth getting this set up and running to help understand how users are interacting with your content.
  10. Lastpass: Secure password management across all your devices. Teams version also available.

Data collection, storage and use

If you'd like more information on Data collection, storage and use and on the changes to regulation under GDPR, you should start with the blogs, training videos, tools, checklists relating at the ICO website.

How are charities using data?

  • Blog about how to use data for good from Steve Maclaughlin, the author of The Data Driven Nonprofit.
  • A free (registration required) report on how organisations are using data to improve their fundraising from Just Giving.
  • An article in the Stanford Social Innovation Review on using 'lean data' to measure social impact more effectively.
  • A report on how charities are increasingly using digital tools to improve their evaluation.
{{else}} {{#compare @root.request.params.query.topic "===" "cyber" ~}}

The area that you selected as your highest priority was cyber resilience and online threats

You scored {{> to_percentage score=@root.request.params.query.s4 lower=-2 upper=17}}% compared to an average of {{round @root.data.supplimentaryResponses.data_averages.aggregations.cyber_resilience_stats.avg "up"}}% for all organisations who have completed the checkup.

Board level responsibility

Protecting the organisation’s online security is as much the board’s responsibility as ensuring that staff, finances and possessions are kept safe in an office environment. The risks should be assessed and Pro-active management of the cyber risk at Board level is critical. Further information can be found at 10 Steps: A Board Level Responsibility

What should you do now to protect yourselves?

The National Cyber Security Centre has produced guidance 'Cyber Security: Small Charity Guide' as well as their threat report 'Charity Sector Threat Assessment' to help charities be aware of the threats and take appropriate actions to protect themselves.

Follow the advice of the National Cyber Security Centre to reduce the risks to your organisation by:

  • Keeping your organisation’s software patches up to date
  • Using proper antivirus software services
  • Educate and train your staff to be cyber-aware

What should you do in the longer term?

Cyber-attacks are as great a risk as other forms of crime. Therefore voluntary sector organisations should:

  • Ensure your information security and cyber threats are included on your risk register and monitored at Board level. Trustees should be asking: Do you we have adequate controls to defend against cyber-attacks? Are we confident in our ability to recover quickly should the worst happen?
  • Consider providing regular training for staff on basic digital skills, information security and data protection.
  • Consider external accreditation, such as Cyber Essentials, to assess your defence against cyber threats.
{{else}} {{/compare ~}} {{/compare ~}} {{/compare ~}} {{/compare ~}} {{/if ~}}

Next steps

Sign up to our e-bulletin to get details of our events, training and other support for digital change.

{{> breadcrumbs}}
{{> headers_splash}}
{{{@root.data.primaryResponse.hits.hits.[0]._source.rendered.scvo_full}}}

Quick guide

Note: This information does not constitute as legal advice and merely serves to provide an indication – visit the Home Office website for more detailed information.

Q1. Do you currently live in the UK?

Q2. Do you intend to arrive in the UK before or after 29 March 2019?

Q2. Do you have indefinite leave to remain status?

Q3. Have you lived in the UK for more than five years?

You will be able to apply to stay in the UK until you have reached the five-year threshold.

Once you have been in the UK continually for five years, you will be able to apply to stay indefinitely by getting 'settled status'. That means you will be free to continue living here and have access to public funds and services.

Getting this status will prove (for example, to employers or public service providers) that you have permission to continue living and working here in future.

The application fee will be no more than the cost charged to British citizens for a UK passport and the online process for application should be in place by late 2018. You can sign up for email updates about this.

Family members who are living with, or join, you in the UK by 29 March 2019 will also be able to apply for settled status after five years in the UK. Close family members (spouses, civil and unmarried partners, dependent children and grandchildren, and dependent parents and grandparents) will be able to join EU citizens after the UK leaves the EU, as long as the relationship existed on 29 March 2019.

If you arrive in the UK during the 'implementation period' (30 March 2019 - 31 December 2020), you will be able to live, work and study in the UK as you would normally. However, you will be required to register with the Home Office if you intend to stay for longer than three months.

The exact details of what will be required of EU citizens arriving during this period is uncertain and remains subject to negotiations between the UK and EU. However, it is proposed that EU citizens who do register during this period will be given the right to stay for a period of five years, at which point you and your family could apply for 'settled status'.

For EU citizens arriving after 31 December 2020, new immigration rules will be in place. Details of these rules are not yet known.

Your 'indefinite leave to remain' status is not affected by the UK leaving the EU. However, should you wish to exchange your existing indefinite leave to remain document for the new 'settled status' document, you will be able to do so free of charge.

You may wish to keep proof of your 'indefinite leave to remain' status in a safe place - in case this is required.

Close family members (spouses, civil and unmarried partners, dependent children and grandchildren, and dependent parents and grandparents) will be able to join you after the UK leaves the EU, as long as the relationship existed on 29 March 2019.

NB. This information applies to citizens of the "EU27" minus citizens of Ireland (whose right to live and reside in the UK will be unaffected by EU withdrawal). Those states are Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czechia, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, and Sweden. Discussions regarding the future right of citizens from the EFTA states (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, and Switzerland) are ongoing.

templates.utilities_json-to-hbs:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>JSON to HBS</title>
    <style type="text/css">
      html, body {
        margin: 0;
        padding: 0;
        overflow: hidden;
        font-size: 16px;
      }
      textarea {
        width: 50vw;
        height: 100vh;
        border: none;
        box-sizing: border-box;
        background-color: #333333;
        color: #ededed;
        font-size: 1rem;
        line-height: 1.5rem;
        background-image: linear-gradient(#222222 50%, #2a2a2a 50%);
        background-size: 100% 3rem;
        background-attachment: local;
        background-position-y: 10px;
        padding: 10px;
        font-family: monospace;
        resize: none;
        outline: none;
        cursor: text;
      }
      #input {
        border-right: 1px solid #cccccc;
        float: left;
      }
      #input::-webkit-scrollbar { width: 0 !important }
      #output {
        border-left: 1px solid #cccccc;
        float: right;
      }
    </style>
  </head>
  <body>
    <textarea id="input" autofocus></textarea>
    <textarea id="output" readonly></textarea>
    <script>
      var inputEl = document.getElementById('input');
      var outputEl = document.getElementById('output');
      var isSyncingInputScroll = false;
      var isSyncingOutputScroll = false;

      inputEl.addEventListener('change', convert);
      inputEl.addEventListener('keyup', convert);

      inputEl.addEventListener('scroll', function() {
        if (!isSyncingInputScroll) {
          isSyncingOutputScroll = true;
          outputEl.scrollTop = inputEl.scrollTop;
        }
        isSyncingInputScroll = false;
      });
      outputEl.addEventListener('scroll', function() {
        if (!isSyncingOutputScroll) {
          isSyncingInputScroll = true;
          inputEl.scrollTop = outputEl.scrollTop;
        }
        isSyncingOutputScroll = false;
      });

      inputEl.addEventListener('select', function(evt) {
        console.log('Selected', evt);
      });

      function convert() {
        let input = inputEl.value;
        try {
          input = JSON.parse(input);
          input = JSON.stringify(input, null, 2);
          inputEl.value = input;
          output.value = input.replace(/^(\s*)(.*?\:\s)?(.*?)\s*(,)?$/gm, function (match, indentation, key, value, trailingComma) {
            key = key ? ' key=' + key.substr(0, key.length - 2) : '';
            let line;
            const type = value.substr(0, 1) === '[' ? ' type="array"' : ''

            switch (value) {
              case ('{'): case ('['):
                line = '\{{#json' + key + type + '}}';
                break;
              case ('{}'): case ('[]'):
                line = '\{{#json' + key + type + '}}\{{/json}}';
                break;
              case ('}'): case(']'):
                line = '\{{/json}}';
                break;
              default:
                if (key) {
                  line = '\{{{json' + key + ' value=' + value + '}}}'
                } else {
                  line = value;
                }
            }

            return (indentation || '') + line + (trailingComma || '');
          });
        } catch(err) {
          const positionIndex = err.message.indexOf('position');
          if (positionIndex > -1) {
            const position = parseInt(err.message.substr(positionIndex + 9), 10);
            inputEl.selectionStart = position;
            inputEl.selectionEnd = position;
          }
          output.value = err.message + '\n' + err.stack;
        }
      }
    </script>
  </body>
</html>
